titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: This day at 12 oclock, with my wife, Mrs. John Adams, and her daughter, Mary Louisa, I took the Cars, for Baltimore— We were accompanied, by Margaret Delany, and Albert Putnam, but we were detained, a full hour, by the failure of the train from Baltimore, to reach Washington, in proper time, and when we arrived at Baltimore, the Steamer in which we had proposed to proceed to Philadelphia this evening, was gone, and we took lodgings for the day at Barnum’s Hotel— In the evening, Mrs. Eleanor Goods joined us from Washington— We sent word to Mr. Christopher Hughes, of our arrival at Baltimore, and he called to see us in the evening—

At nine oclock this morning, we took the Train of Cars, for Philadelphia— Mr. Hughes called upon us again before our departure— We arrived at Philadelphia about three oclock P.M. and took lodgings at the Columbia House, in Chesnut Street. opposite to the Union Hotel, heretofore kept by Mr. Jones. an Englishman, which is now transferred to other Proprietors— The Columbia House is kept by Mr. Hartwell— My wife, Mrs. John and her daughter went to visit Miss Mease in the evening— I ventured, rashly, to stroll out, and take a walk, in Chesnut Street— I met successively, Captain Henry of the Navy and a Mr. Townsend, each of whom walked with me—

We proceeded, in a Steamer from Philadelphia to Bristol, and from thence, by the Railway to New York— We crossed the river, in the Ferry Boat, and took lodgings, at the City Hotel, at three oclock We had visits from Mrs. and Miss Renwick, and Mr. Renwick, and from Alexander. S. Johnson. We confined ourselves to the house, on account of the rain.

Heavy rain all night, and the former part of this day— We had been invited, to attend the
Consecration of Calvary Church, of which Mr. Samuel. L. Southard, the son, of my deceased friend of that name—is to be the Rector—but the state of my health prevented me from attending nor did any of us go— We confined ourselves again, except occasional walks in Broadway, where we met General Gaines and his Lady, who had visited us by cards at the Hotel— At four oclock P.M— we left New York, in a Steamer for Hartford in which about eleven at night, we entered Connecticut river at Saybrook, and proceeded up the river till about five oclock in the morning—

We landed at Hartford and breakfasted at the City Hotel, immediately after which, at Seven oclock, we took the Train of Railway Cars, through Springfield and Worcester to Boston—where we arrived, about one oclock— After waiting until quarter past two, took the Cars of the Old Colony Railroad, to Quincy. We met at the Cars, my Son Charles Francis Adams, his daughter, Louisa Catherine and his son Charles. Francis. At a quarter before three, we landed at the Depot, and I walked, to my own residence. We found my Son and his family, God be praised, in good health, and he with his wife, spent the evening with us. In the Cars at Springfield, we met William, C. Johnson, who was going on, to meet his sister Sarah, who is on a visit to her friends, in Boston and Quincy, and who was to return with him to Utica— Mr. & Mrs. Kirk have left the house, and their connexion with us, and in their place, are a young man and his wife by the name of Hutchinson—

I had born the Journey from Washington rather better than I had expected, but had a very restless and agitated night, which was quieted only by a dose of Paregoric, taken after midnight.
Yet I found myself this morning, somewhat restored, to tranquility, and attended Public Worship, at the Stone Temple, morning and afternoon— It was the Communion day, at which, much to my satisfaction, I participated in the ceremony— Mr. Lunt preached, in the morning, from Matthew 12.35, “A good man, out of the good treasure of the heart, bringeth forth good things”—and in the afternoon, from Acts, 4.12. [“]neither is there Salvation, in any other, for there is none other name, under Heaven, given among Men, whereby we must be saved.” William. C. Johnson, came out this day, with his sister Sarah, and dined with us— They went in to Boston again, and Mary Louisa, went with them, to hear the Oratorio, of Moses in Egypt, performed by a company of Italian musicians—

I had a more comfortable night, than the preceeding one, and hope it has restored me, to a state not more disordered, than I was before leaving Washington— I had a visit from the late President Quincy, who proposes, to come with his family, from Boston, to reside at his Seat in Quincy, during the Summer months, tomorrow— I answered the Letter of Mr. C. S. Daveis, of Portland Maine, proposing, as Chairman of a Committee, of the Massachusetts Cincinnati Society, to come and present to me an invitation, to attend their Anniversary Celebration on the next fourth of July, which invitation, I am from the state of my health, compelled to decline— Before dinner I walked up to my Son’s House, and met there his son John Quincy, with three of his companions, one a son of Mr. Emmons, and two sons of Dr. John. G. Palfrey, just returned from the Latin School at Boston— In the afternoon, towards Sunset, I took a ride, with my daughters, Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams—

My Granddaughter Mary Louisa, went into Boston
this morning, and returned before dinner, with Sarah. Adams. Johnson, of Utica, the Granddaughter of my brother Charles—who comes to stay for a short time with us— I answered, the Letter of David. D. Field—Secretary of the Committee of Arrangements for a public dinner, to be given to Henry Wheaton, at New-York, on the 10th. of this month— Mr Wheaton has just returned, from a series of Diplomatic missions, in Europe, to which he was first appointed by me, more than twenty years ago, and in which he has distinguished himself, by the publication of several important works— I am compelled in this case also, to decline the invitation to partake of this festivity— I answered also, a Letter, from Judge William Jay, of Bedford, New York, who enclosed to me, copies, of two anonymous Letters, written from Amsterdam in January and May 1782. to Dr. Franklin against my Father; which proved perfectly harmless to him but had the singular effect, of producing, a bitter and violent controversy between Henry Laurens, and Edmund Jennings, who published counter pamphlets, but in which controversy, my Father took no part— Jennings, was a most intimate friend and correspondent of my Father’s during several years of the War, but Mr. Laurens, I never knew why, suspected, that he was the author, of these anonymous Letters— They excited, great sensation at the time, which continued for several years— The Author, was some obscure, and low-lived English Spy, but I never knew, nor did my Father I believe, who he was— Judge Jay, seems not aware, that I was acquainted with these papers, though they had been well known to me, from very shortly after their first composition— I rode with my two daughters in the afternoon, and had as visitors, a man from Pittsburgh calling his name McElroy, who complained, that he had been sent, by his relations to an Insane Hospital at Brattleborough Vermont, from which he was
now, returning to Pittsburgh; and from a person belonging to Boston, named, Farnham. who appeared to have no other motive to see me, than curiosity. The ladies went to a party at Mr. Lunts, where they had an Exhibition of Tableaux—

I had again, a quiet and comfortable night’s rest, and all this day, was in that state of health, which I have had upon an average, since the close of the Session of Congress— That I shall ever be better, I have scarce any reason to expect, how long this state will continue, I must leave to the disposal of events— It disqualifies me for all business, and I can write, any thing more than my name, only, with the aid of my Granddaughter, or her mother— My son’s wife, kindly offered me, the same favor, and my own wife, does the same— It can hardly be called life, but tis the destiny ordained for me, and at which. I ought not to repine— I passed a quiet day. and with the help of Mary Louisa, resumed my Diary, from the day of our leaving Washington— I walked before dinner, to my Son’s House on the hill, but he and his wife, were both in Boston, and Mrs. John Adams, who returned to dinner— In the afternoon towards sunset, I rode to Milton, returning by Braintree, and my Son, with his son John, passed the evening here— The Letters to Judge Jay, and to D. D. Field were dispatched, and this evening, the keys of our Trunks, which had been left behind at Washington, and for which my wife had written were received by the mail—

I had morning visits from Mr. Jonathan Baxter, together with Mr. Shepley, a Clergyman, from the State of Maine, also from a black man by the name of Moses Saylor, who came for two purposes, to solicit contributions, first to make up a sum, of many hundred dollars, to redeem from Slavery, his brother
and his family, and secondly, to pay the debts. of a Church for people of color, in the State of Maryland. I declined both, and gave him a dollar for himself, as I understood him, he had been, a slave of Francis Thomas. sometime a Member of Congress, and afterwards Governor of Maryland— His brother and family also belonged to Thomas—but he having failed in his pecuniary concerns they had been sold as part of his property, to pay his debts— The sum required to purchase their freedom I think he said was $750—of which he had collected so much as left about four hundred dollars still to be contributed— Thomas, was distinguished as an able member of Congress, but has been much more so; for controversies, with his wife, and several of her relations. My Granddaughter Mary Louisa, and Sarah Johnson, went upon a party to Squantum, with Isaac Hull, Joseph Harrod, Elizabeth. C. Adams, and Mrs. Stebbins, where they dined, and spent the evening at Elizabeth. C. Adams house— I walked before dinner, to my Son’s house, and rode towards evening, with my wife, and Louisa. C. Smith— After our return, my wife was, quite ill, and took to her bed— I was myself not a little indisposed—

I had a more quiet night, than I expected— I have been reading a Book, called the Life of Emanuel Swedenborg. given me, on the 4th. July 1845, by Mr. Hobart of Abington, in which Town, there is a Swedenborgian or New Jerusalem Church— I have made fruitless exertions to understand the character of this man, and of his pretended Revelations, without success— He pretended to have personal and frequent conversations, with God himself, with Angels, with spirits Good and bad, and with persons deceased— He says in the Letter, to a Rev Dr. Hartly an Englishman, after giving some account of his early life “But I regard all that I have mentioned, as matters of respectively little moment, for what far exceeds them, I have been called, to a Holy Office, by the Lord himself, who most graciously manifested himself in person to me his Servant in the year 1745. when he opened my sight to the view of the Spiritual world and granted me, the privilege of conversing, with spirits and Angels, which I enjoy to this day— From that time, I began to print and publish, various.[”]
